*)andrei=o/n ge pa/nu nomi/zomen, o(\s a)\n peplh/gh| pate/ra we always consider one very manly who has (may have) beaten his father. AR. Av. 1350.
*no/mon qh/sein mhdeni\ tw=n *(ellh/nwn u(ma=s bohqei=n o(\s a)\n mh\ pro/teros bebohkw\s u(mi=n h)=|, to enact a law that you shall assist no one of the Greeks who shall not previously have assisted you. DEM. xix. 16. (Ὃς ἂν μὴ πρότερος βοηθῇ would mean who shall not previously assist you.)
*)/edeisan mh\ lu/ssa h(mi=n e)mpeptw/koi, they feared lest madness might prove to have fallen upon us. XEN. An. v. 7, 26. (Μὴ ἐμπίπτοι would mean lest it might fall upon us.)
*)edeh/qhn tw=n dikastw=n mhde\n toiou=ton pra=cai, i(/n' e)gw\ mhde/na *)aqhnai/wn a)pektonw\s ei)/hn that I might not be in the position of having put an Athenian to death. DEM. liii. 18.
*)\hn ga\r eu(reqh=| le/gwn soi\ tau)/t', e)/gwg' a)\n e)kpefeugoi/hn pa/qos I should (in that case) have escaped harm. SOPH. OT 839.
*pw=s ou)k a)\n oi)ktro/tata pa/ntwn e)gw\ peponqw\s ei)/hn, ei) e)me\ yhfi/sainto ei)=nai ce/non; how should I not have suffered the most pitiable of all things, if they should vote me to be an alien? DEM. lvii. 44. (This could have been expressed, with a very slight difference in meaning, πῶς οὐ πεπονθὼς ἔσομαι, ἐὰν ψηφίσωνται; how shall I not have suffered, etc.)
*ei) o(tiou=n peponqw\s e(ka/teros h(mw=n ei)/h, ou) kai\ a)mfo/teroi a)\n tou=to pepo/nqoimen; if each of us should have suffered anything whatsoever, would not both of us have suffered it? PLAT. Hipp. M. 301 A.
*ou)k a)\n dia\ tou=to/ g' ei)=en ou)k eu)qu\s dedwko/tes this, at least, cannot be the reason why they did not pay it at once; lit.they would not (on inquiry) prove to have not paid it at once on this account. DEM. xxx. 10.

The perfect subjunctive in protasis corresponds exactly to the Latin future perfect indicative; but the Greek seldom uses this cumbrous perfect, preferring the less precise aorist (91). The perfect optative, in both protasis and apodosis, corresponds to the Latin perfect subjunctive; but it is seldom used, for a similar reason (95).

The perfect optative can hardly be accurately expressed in English. For when we use the English forms would have suffered and should have suffered to translate the perfect optative, these are merely vaguer expressions for will and shall have suffered. (See the examples above.) I should have suffered is commonly past in English, being equivalent to ἔπαθον ἄν; but here it is future, and is therefore liable to be misunderstood. There is no more reference to past time, however, in the perfect optative with ἄν, than there is in the future perfect indicative (77) in such expressions as ma/thn e)moi\ keklau/setai, I shall have had my whippings for nothing (referring to those received in his boyhood), AR. Nub. 1436.

The perfect imperative is most common in the third person singular of the passive, where it expresses a command that something just done or about to be done shall be decisive and final. It is thus equivalent to the perfect participle with ἔστω. E.g.
*tau=ta me\n dh\ tau/th| ei)rh/sqw let so much have been thus said, (= εἰρημένα ἔστω), i.e. let what has been thus said be sufficient. PLAT. Crat. 401D. But o(/mws de\ ei)rh/sqw o(/ti, k.t.l. still let as much as this (which follows) be said (once for all), that, etc. Rep. 607C .
*peri\ tw=n i)di/wn tau=ta/ moi proeirh/sqw, let this have been said (once for all) by way of introduction. ISOC. iv. 14.
*tau=ta pepai/sqw te u(mi=n, kai\ i)/sws i(kanw=s e)/xei let this be the end of the play, etc. PLAT. Euthyd. 278D.
*teta/xqw h(mi=n kata\ dhmokrati/an o( toiou=tos a)nh/r, let such a man remain (where we have placed him), corresponding to democracy. Rep. 561E.
*)apeirga/sqw dh\ h(mi=n au(/th h( politei/a, let this now be a sufficient description of this form of government. Ib. 553A.
*me/xri tou=de w(ri/sqw u(mw=n h( braduth/s, at this point let the limit of your sluggishness be fixed. THUC. i. 71.

The third person plural in the same sense could be expressed by the perfect participle with ἔστων, as in PLAT. Rep. 502 A, ou(=toi toi/nun tou=to pepeisme/noi e)/stwn , grant then that these have been persuaded of this.

On this principle the perfect imperative is used in mathematical language, to imply that something is to be considered as proved or assumed once for all, or that lines drawn or points fixed are to remain as data for a following demonstration. E.g. *ei)lh/fqw e)pi\ th=s *a*b tuxo\n shmei=on to\ *d, kai\ a)fh|rh/sqw a)po\ th=s *a*g th=| *a*d i)/sh h( *a*e let any point D be assumed as taken in the line AB, and AE, equal to AD, as cut off from AC. EUCL. i. 9

The perfect imperative of the second person is rare; when it is used, it seems to be a little more emphatic than the present or aorist. E.g.
*)he\ su\ to/nde de/deco Il. v. 228.
*mh\ pefo/bhsqe, do not be afraid. THUC. vi. 17.
*mo/non su\ h(mi=n pista\ qew=n pepoi/hso kai\ decia\n do/s only make us (immediately or once for all) solemn pledges and give the right hand. XEN. Cyr. iv. 2, 7.
*pe/pauso, stop! not another word! DEM. xxiv. 64.

In verbs whose perfect has the force of a present (49) the perfect imperative is the ordinary form; as μέμνησο, κεκλήσθω, ἕσταθι, ἑστάτω, τέθναθι, τεθνάτω, ἴστω. So kexh/nate, AR. Ach. 133 ; mh\ kekra/gate, Vesp. 415 . The perfect imperative active seems to have been used only in such verbs. Occasionally we find the periphrastic form with the participle and εἰμί, as e)/stw cumbebhkui=a, Leg. 736

The perfect infinitive not in indirect discourse generally represents an act as finished when the present would represent it as going on (96). E.g.
*ou)de\ bouleu/esqai e)/ti w(/ra, a)lla\ bebouleu=sqai: th=s ga\r e)piou/shs nukto\s pa/nta tau=ta dei= pepra=xqai it is no longer time even to be deliberating, but (it is time) to have done deliberating; for all this must be finished within the coming night. PLAT. Crit. 46A.
*kai\ mh\n peri\ w(=n ge proseta/cate prosh/kei diw|khke/nai, and it is his duty to have attended to the business about which you gave him instructions. DEM. xix. 6. (This refers to an ambassador presenting his accounts on his return.)
*cunetu/gxane pollaxou= dia\ th\n stenoxwri/an ta\ me\n a)/llois e)mbeblhke/nai ta\ d' au)tou\s e)m beblh=sqai, du/o te peri\ mi/an cunhrth=sqai it often befell them to have made an attack on one side and (at the same time) to have been attacked themselves on the other, etc. THUC. vii. 70.
*)ana/gkh ga\r ta\ me\n me/gist' au)tw=n h)/dh katakexrh=sqai mikra\ de/ tina paralelei=fqai for it must be that the most important subjects have been used up, and that only unimportant ones have been left. ISOC. iv. 74.
*ou)k h)/qelon e)mbai/nein dia\ to\ katapeplh=xqai th=| h(/ssh|, they were unwilling to embark on account of having been terrified by the defeat. THUC. vii. 72.
*to\ ga\r polla\ a)polwleke/nai kata\ to\n po/lemon th=s h(mete/ras a)melei/as a)/n tis qei/h dikai/ws, to\ de\ mh/te pa/lai tou=to peponqe/nai pefhne/nai te/ tina h(mi=n summaxi/an tou/twn a)nti/rropon, th=s par' e)kei/nwn eu)noi/as eu)erge/thm' a)\n e)/gwge qei/hn for our having lost many things during the war one might justly charge upon our neglect; but our never having suffered this before, and the fact that an alliance has now appeared to us to make up for these losses, I should consider a benefaction, etc. DEM. i. 10. (Compare γεγενῆσθαι in the first example under 103.)
*)/efqasan paroikodomh/santes, w(/ste mhke/ti mh/te au)toi\ kwlu/esqai u(p' au)tw=n, e)kei/nous te kai\ panta/pasin a)pesterhke/nai . . . sfa=s a)poteixi/sai, i.e. they carried their own wall first beyond that of the Athenians, so as no longer to be themselves interfered with by them, and so as to have effectually prevented them from walling them in. THUC. vii. 6.
*)epemelh/qh kai\ tw=n loipw=n, w(/ste tw=n paro/ntwn toi=s a)nqrw/pois a)gaqw=n mhde\n me\n a)/neu th=s po/lews ei)=nai, ta\ de\ plei=sta dia\ tau/thn gegenh=sqai ISOC. iv. 38.
*toiau=ta kai\ tosau=ta kateskeu/asan h(mi=n, w(/ste mhdeni\ tw=n e)pigignome/nwn u(perbolh\n lelei=fqai, they made such and so great acquisitions as to have no possibility of surpassing them left to any one who should come after them. DEM. iii. 25.
*di/domen au)toi=s proi=ka sugkeko/fqai we allow them to have cut us up for nothing (i.e. we make no account of their having done so). AR. Nub. 1426.

See [ARISTOT.] Nic. vi. 2. 6: ou)k e)/sti de\ proaireto\n ou)de\n gegono\s, oi(=on ou)dei\s proairei=tai *)/ilion peporqhke/nai , but nothing past can be purposed; for example, nobody purposes to have sacked Ilium, i.e. the expression προαιροῦμαι Ἴλιον πεπορθηκέναι would be nonsense. This illustrates well the restricted use of the perfect infinitive.

The perfect infinitive sometimes signifies that the action is to be decisive and permanent (like the perfect imperative, 105); and sometimes it seems to be merely more emphatic than the present or aorist infinitive. E.g.
*ei)=pon th\n qu/ran keklei=sqai they ordered that the door should be shut (and remain so) XEN. Hell. v. 4, 7.
*boulo/menos a)gw=ni kai\ dikasthri/w| moi diwri/sqai par' u(mi=n o(/ti ta)nanti/a e)moi\ kai\ tou/tois pe/praktai i.e.wishing to have it once for all settled in your minds. DEM. xix. 223.
*qelou/sas pro\s pu/lais peptwke/nai, eager to fall before the gates. AESCH. Sept. 462.
*)/hlaunen e)pi\ tou\s *me/nwnos, w(/st' e)kei/nous e)kpeplh=xqai kai\ tre/xein e)pi\ ta\ o(/pla he marched against the soldiers of Menon, so that they were (once for all) thoroughly frightened and ran to arms. XEN. An. i. 5, 13. (Here ἐκπεπλῆχθαι is merely more emphatic than the present or aorist would be.)

div2.head: Future.
div2.p: The future is used in the dependent moods only in the optative and the infinitive, and in these it is never regular except in indirect discourse and kindred constructions and in the periphrastic form with μέλλω (73).
For the future optative in indirect discourse see 128-134; for the future infinitive in indirect discourse see 135 and 136.

In constructions out of indirect discourse the present and aorist infinitive can always refer to future time if the context requires it (96), so that the future infinitive is here rarely needed. Therefore, after verbs which naturally have a future action as their object but yet do not introduce indirect discourse,—as those of commanding, wishing, etc. (684),—the present or aorist infinitive (not the future) is regularly used. Thus the Greek expresses they wish to do this not by βούλονται τοῦτο ποιήσειν, but by βούλονται τοῦτο ποιεῖν (or ποιῆσαι). So the infinitive in other future expressions, as after ὥστε and in its final sense, is generally present or aorist. (For the single exception after μέλλω, see 73.)

On the other hand, when it was desired to make the reference to the future especially prominent, the future infinitive could be used exceptionally in all these cases. Thus we sometimes find the future after verbs signifying to be able, to wish, to be unwilling, and the like; sometimes also in a final sense or with ὥστε and ἐφ’ ᾧτε; and sometimes when the infinitive with the article refers to future time. This use of the future is a partial adoption of the form of indirect discourse in other constructions. It was a particularly favourite usage with Thucydides. E.g.
*)edeh/qhsan de\ kai\ tw=n *megare/wn nausi\ sfa=s cumprope/myein, they asked the Megareans also to escort them with ships. THUC. i. 27.
*)ebou/lonto protimwrh/sesqai Id. vi. 57. So e)pixeirh/sein e)qelh/seis; AESCHIN. iii. 152.
*to\ sto/ma au)tou= dienoou=nto klh/|sein THUC. vii. 56.
*)efie/menoi me\n th=s pa/shs a)/rcein, bohqei=n de\ a(/ma eu)prepw=s boulo/menoi toi=s e(autw=n cuggene/si kai\ cumma/xois Id. vi. 6. (Here βοηθεῖν is regular.)
*tou= tai=s nausi\ mh\ a)qumei=n e)pixeirh/sein, to prevent them from being without spirit to attack them in ships. Id. vii. 21.
*ou)/t' a)pokwlu/sein du/natoi o)/ntes Id. iii. 28.
*ei) de/ g' e)n lo/gois pei/sein dunhso/mesqa SOPH. Ph. 1394.
*ei)/ tis ei)s tou=to a)naba/lletai poih/sein ta\ de/onta, if any one postpones doing his duty as far as this. DEM. iii. 9. (The ordinary construction would be ἀναβάλλεται ποιεῖν or ποιῆσαι.)
*ou)/te tw=n progo/nwn memnh=sqai [dei=] ou)/te tw=n lego/ntwn a)ne/xesqai, no/mon te qh/sein kai\ gra/yein, k.t.l. DEM. xix. 16. (Here we have δεῖ θήσειν.)
*pollou= de/w e)mauto/n ge a)dikh/sein kai\ kat' e)mautou= e)rei=n au)to/s PLAT. Ap. 37B.
*tou\s o(mh/rous pare/dosan tw=| *)argei/wn dh/mw| dia\ tau=ta diaxrh/sesqai, that they might put them to death. THUC. vi. 61. So πεύσεσθαι, Id. iii. 26.
*)ef' w(=|te bohqh/sein AESCHIN. iii. 114 (see 610).
*)apodei/cw au)to\n th\n proi=ka ou) dedwko/ta ou(/tw mega/lois tekmhri/ois w(/ste u(ma=s a(/pantas ei)/sesqai DEM. xxx. 5 : so xxix. 5.
*)elpi/di to\ a)fane\s tou= katorqw/sein e)pitre/yantes, having committed to hope what was uncertain in the prospect of success. THUC. ii. 42. (Here κατορθώσειν is more explicit than the present κατορθοῦν would be: τὸ ἀφανὲς τοῦ κατορθοῦν would mean simply what was uncertain in regard to success.)
*tou= e)s xei=ras e)lqei=n pisto/teron to\ e)kfobh/sein h(ma=s a)kindu/nws h(gou=ntai, they feel more confidence in the prospect of frightening us without risk than in meeting us in battle. Id. iv. 126.
*to\ me\n ou)=n e)cele/gcein au)to\n qarrw= kai\ pa/nu pisteu/w, I have courage and great confidence as to my convicting him. DEM. xix. 3. (Here most of the ordinary MSS. read ἐξελέγχειν.)

See also THUC. iv. 115 and 121, THUC. v. 35, THUC. vii. 11, THUC. viii. 55 and 74; and Krüger's note on i. 27, where these passages are cited. In several of these there is some MS. authority for the aorist infinitive.
The future perfect infinitive occurs only in indirect discourse (137), except in verbs whose perfect has the sense of a present (82).

div2.head: Optative and Infinitive of Indirect Discourse.
div2.p: When the optative and infinitive are in indirect discourse, each tense represents the corresponding tense of the direct discourse; the present including also the imperfect, and the perfect also the pluperfect.

See the general principles of indirect discourse (667). The optative is included here only as it is used after past tenses to represent an indicative or subjunctive of the direct discourse. No cases of the optative or infinitive with ἄν are considered here: for these see Chapter III. For the meaning of the term indirect discourse as applied to the infinitive, see 684.

div2.head: Present Optative.
div2.p: The present optative in indirect discourse may represent the following forms of direct discourse:—

1. The present indicative of a leading verb. E.g.
*periklh=s prohgo/reue, o(/ti *)arxi/damo/s oi( ce/nos ei)/h Pericles announced that Archidamus was his friend (i.e. he said ξένος μοί ἐστιν). THUC. ii. 13.
*)/egnwsan o(/ti keno\s o( fo/bos ei)/h they learned that their fear was groundless (i.e. they learned κενός ἐστιν ὁ φόβος) XEN. An. ii. 2, 21.
*)epunqa/neto ei) oi)koi=to h( xw/ra he asked whether the country was inhabited (i.e. he asked the question οἰκεῖται ἡ χώρα;) XEN. Cyr. iv. 4, 4.

2. The present indicative or subjunctive of a dependent verb. E.g.
*ei)=pen o(/ti a)/ndra a)/goi o(\n ei(=rcai de/oi he said that he was bringing a man whom it was necessary to confine (he said ἄνδρα ἄγω ὃν εἷρξαι δεῖ). XEN. Hell. v. 4, 8.
*(hgei=to a(/pan poih/sein au)to\n ei)/ tis a)rgu/rion didoi/h he believed that the man would do anything if one were to give him money (he believed ἅπαν ποιήσει ἐάν τις ἀργύριον διδῷ). LYS. xii. 14.

3. The present subjunctive in a question of appeal (287). E.g.
*kle/arxos e)bouleu/eto, ei) pe/mpoie/n tinas h)\ pa/ntes i)/oien, Clearchus was deliberating whether they should send a few or should all go. XEN. An. i. 10, 5. (The question was, πέμπωμέν τινας ἢ πάντες ἴωμεν; shall we send a few, or shall we all go? See 677.) The context will always make it clear whether the optative represents a subjunctive (as here) or an indicative (1).

4. The imperfect indicative of a leading verb. E.g.
*)apekri/nanto o(/ti ou)dei\s ma/rtus parei/h they replied that no witness had been present (when a certain payment was made). DEM. xxx. 20. (They said οὐδεὶς παρῆν.)
This is the rare imperfect optative (673). The imperfect indicative is regularly retained in such cases, and is always retained in a dependent clause of a quotation (689, 2).

div2.head: Present Infinitive.
div2.p:
Verbs of hoping and swearing may thus take the present infinitive in indirect discourse. This must be distinguished from the more common use of the present and aorist infinitive (not in indirect discourse) after these verbs, referring to the future (100; 136). E.g.
*)elpi/zwn ei)=nai a)nqrw/pwn o)libw/tatos, tau=ta e)peirw/ta he asked this, trusting that he was the most happy of men. HDT. i. 30.
So i. 22, e)lpi/zwn sitodei/hn te ei)=nai i)sxurh\n kai\ to\n lew\n tetru=sqai.
*cuna\ d' e)lpi/zw le/gein, and I hope I speak for the common good. AESCH. Sept. 76.
*)omnu/ntes ble/pein to\n ou)ke/t' o)/nta zw=nt' *)axille/a pa/lin i.e. swearing that they saw Achilles alive again. SOPH. Ph. 357.

Compare the first two examples with e)lpi/zei du/natos ei)=nai he hopes to be able, PLAT. Rep. 573 C ; and the last with o)mo/sai ei)=nai me
 th
 a)rxh
 koinh
, pa/ntas d' u(mi=n a)podou=nai th
 xw/ran to swear that the dominion shall be common, and that all shall surrender the land, DEM. xxiii. 170. (See 136 and the examples.)

(As Imperfect.) The present infinitive may also represent an imperfect indicative of the direct discourse, thus supplying the want of an imperfect infinitive. E.g.
*ti/nas ou)=n eu)xa\s u(polamba/net' eu)/xesqai toi=s qeoi=s to\n *fi/lippon o(/t' e)/spenden; what prayers then do you suppose Philip made to the Gods when he was pouring his libations? DEM. xix. 130. (Here the temporal clause ὅτ’ ἔσπενδεν shows that εὔχεσθαι is past.)
*po/ter' oi)/esqe ple/on *fwke/as *qhbai/wn h)\ *fi/lippon u(mw=n kratei=n tw=| pole/mw|; do you think that the superiority of the Phocians over the Thebans or that of Philip over you was the greater in the war (the war being then past)? DEM. xix. 148. (Here the direct discourse would be ἐκράτουν and ἐκράτει.)
*pw=s ga\r oi)/esqe dusxerw=s a)kou/ein *)olunqi/ous, ei)/ ti/s ti le/goi kata\ *fili/ppou kat' e)kei/nous tou\s xro/nous o(/t' *)anqemou=nta au)toi=s a)fi/ei; . . . a)=ra prosdoka=n au)tou\s toiau=ta pei/sesqai (sc. οἴεσθε); [hellip] a)=r' oi)/esqe, o(/te tou\s tura/nnous e)ce/balle, (tou\s *qettalou\s) prosdoka=n, k.t.l.; for how unwillingly do you think the Olynthians used to hear it, if any one said anything against Philip in those times when he was ceding Anthemus to them, etc.? Do you think they were expecting to suffer such things? Do you think that the Thessalians, when he was expelling the despots, were expecting, etc.? DEM. vi. 20 and 22. (The direct questions were πῶς ἤκουον εἰ λέγοι; and προσεδόκων;)
*kai\ ga\r tou\s e)pi\ tw=n progo/nwn h(mw=n le/gontas a)kou/w tou/tw| tw=| e)/qei xrh=sqai, I hear that they used to follow this custom. DEM. iii. 21.
*ta\ me\n pro\ *(/ellhnos ou)de\ ei)=nai h( e)pi/klhsis au(/th (sc. δοκεῖ), in the times before Hellen this name does not appear to have even existed. THUC. i. 3.
Again, in the same sentence of Thucydides, παρέχεσθαι, to have furnished.
*mhde\n oi)/ou a)/llo mhxana=sqai h)\ o(/pws . . . de/cointo, i(/na . . . gi/gnoito PLAT. Rep. 430A.
*meta\ tau=ta e)/fh sfa=s me\n deipnei=n, to\n de\ *swkra/th ou)k ei)sie/nai: to\n ou)=n *)aga/qwna polla/kis keleu/ein metape/myasqai to\n *swkra/th, e(\ de\ ou)k e)a=n
Symp. 175C . (He said, ἐδειπνοῦμεν, ὁ δὲ Σ. οὐκ εἰσῄει· ὁ οὖν Ἀ. ἐκέλευεν· ἐγὼ δὲ οὐκ εἴων.)
*suntuxei=n ga\r (e)/fh) *)atresti/da| para\ *fili/ppou poreuome/nw|, kai\ met' au)tou= gu/naia kai\ paida/ria badi/zein for he said that he had met (aor.) Atrestidas coming from Philip, and that there were walking with him (impf.), etc. DEM. xix. 305.
*tou=t' e)gw/ fhmi dei=n e)me\ mh\ laqei=n, I say that this ought not to have escaped my notice. DEM. xviii. 190. (The direct form was τοῦτ’ ἔδει ἐμὲ μὴ λαθεῖν, 415.)

The imperfect infinitive is found even in Homer; as kai\ se\, ge/ron, to\ pri\n me\n a)kou/omen o)/lbion ei)=nai, we hear that you were once prosperous. Il. xxiv. 543. So Il. v. 639; Od. viii. 181, Od. 8. 516.
For the imperfect participle, see 140.

This use of the present infinitive as an imperfect must be carefully distinguished from its ordinary use after past tenses, where we translate it by the imperfect, as in ἔφη τὸ στράτευμα μάχεσθαι, he said that the army was fighting. This has sometimes been called an imperfect infinitive; but here μάχεσθαι refers to time present relatively to ἔφη; whereas, if it had been used as an imperfect, it would have referred to time past relatively to ἔφη, as in ἔφη τὸ στράτευμα τῇ προτεραίᾳ μάχεσθαι, he said that the army had been fighting on the day before. In the former case the direct discourse was μάχεται, in the latter it was ἐμάχετο. Such an imperfect infinitive differs from the aorist in the same construction only by expressing the duration or repetition of an action (as in the indicative); it gives, in fact, the only means of representing in the infinitive what is usually expressed by λέγει ὅτι ἐποίει, he says that he was doing, as opposed to λέγει ὅτι ἐποίησεν, he says that he did. (For the similar use of the present optative to represent the imperfect, see 116, 4.) This construction is never used unless the context makes it certain that the infinitive represents an imperfect and not a present, so that no ambiguity can arise. See the examples.

So sometimes in Latin: Q. Scaevolam memoria teneo bello Marsico, cum esset summa senectute, cotidie facere omnibus conveniendi potestatem sui. CIC. Phil. viii. 31. So Q. Maximum accepimus facile celare, tacere, dissimulare, insidiari, praeripere hostium consilia. CIC. de Off. i. 108.

div2.head: Perfect Optative.
div2.p: The perfect optative in indirect discourse may represent—

1. The perfect indicative of a leading verb. E.g.
*)/elege o(/sa a)gaqa\ *ku=ros *pe/rsas pepoih/koi, he told how many services Cyrus had done the Persians. HDT. iii. 75. (Πεποιήκοι here represents πεποίηκε.)
*ou(=toi e)/legon w(s pentako/sioi au)toi=s ei)/hsan e)k tou= *peiraiw=s dedekasme/noi LYS. xxix. 12. (Here the direct discourse was πεντακόσιοί εἰσιν δεδεκασμένοι.)

2. The perfect indicative or subjunctive of a dependent verb. E.g.
*ei)=pen o(/ti *de/cippon ou)k e)painoi/h ei) tau=ta pepoihkw\s ei)/h (he said οὐκ ἐπαινῶ εἰ ταῦτα πεποίηκε, I do not approve him if he has done this). XEN. An. vi. 6, 25.
*)ele/gomen o(/ti e(/na e(/kaston e(\n de/oi e)pithdeu/ein, ei)s o(\ au)tou= h( fu/sis e)pithdeiota/th pefukui=a ei)/h (we said ἕκαστον ἓν δεῖ ἐπιτηδεύειν, εἰς ὃ ἂν πεφυκὼς ᾖ, each one is to practise one thing, for which his nature is best fitted; though this might be πέφυκε, like πεποίηκε in the first example). PLAT. Rep. 433A.

div2.head: Perfect Infinitive.
div2.p:
The perfect infinitive in indirect discourse generally represents a perfect indicative of the direct form. E.g.
Φησὶ τοῦτο πεπραχέναι, he says that he has done this;
ἔφη τοῦτο πεπραχέναι, he said that he had done this;
φήσει τοῦτο πεπραχέναι, he will say that he has done this (the direct form in each case being πέπραχα).
*)/efh xrh/maq' e(autw=| tou\s *qhbai/ous e)pikekhruxe/nai, he said that the Thebans had offered a reward for his seizure. DEM. xix. 21.
In AR. Nub. 1277, proskeklh=sqai/ moi dokei=s (according to MSS. Rav. and Ven. ), you seem to me to be sure to be summoned to court (to be as good as already summoned), the infinitive represents a perfect indicative referring to the future (51). There is probably a regard to the perfect of the preceding verse, σεσεῖσθαί μοι δοκεῖς. So THUC. ii. 8: e)n tou/tw| te kekwlu=sqai e)do/kei e(ka/stw| ta\ pra/gmata w(=| mh/ tis au)to\s pare/stai , and each man thought that things were the same as stopped in that matter in which he was not himself to take part. After a verb of swearing:
w)/mnue mhde\n ei)rhke/nai peri\ au)tou= fau=lon, DEM. xxi. 119. . After ἐλπίζω: e)lpi/zwn to\n lew\n tetru=sqai, HDT. i. 22 (see 118, above).

The perfect infinitive rarely represents a pluperfect of the direct form. E.g.
*le/getai a)/ndra e)kpeplh=xqai polu/n tina xro/non e)pi\ tw=| ka/llei tou= *ku/rou it is said that a man had been struck with amazement for some time at the beauty of Cyrus (i.e. ἐξεπέπληκτο). XEN. Cyr. i. 4, 27.
*)ante/legon, le/gontes mh\ e)phgge/lqai pw ta\s sponda\s o(/t' e)se/pemyan tou\s o(pli/tas saying that the truce had not yet been proclaimed (ἐπήγγελτο). THUC. v. 49.

div2.head: Aorist Optative.
div2.p: The aorist optative in indirect discourse may represent—

1. The aorist indicative of a leading verb. E.g.
*)/elecan o(/ti pe/myeie sfa=s o( basileu/s, they said that the king had sent them (i.e. they said ἔπεμψεν ἡμᾶς ὁ βασιλεύς). XEN. Cyr. ii. 4, 7
*to/te e)gnw/sqh o(/ti oi( ba/rbaroi to\n a)/nqrwpon u(pope/myaien, then it became known that the barbarians had sent the man. XEN. An. ii. 4, 22
*)eto/lma le/gein w(s polla\ tw=n e)mw=n la/boien, he dared to say that they had taken (ἔλαβον) much of my property. DEM. xxvii. 49.
*)hrw/twn au)to\n ei) a)napleu/seien e)/xwn a)rgu/rion, I asked him whether he had set sail with money (i.e. I asked him the question, ἀνέπλευσας;). DEM. L. 55. (This form is rare; see 125.)
*)epeirw/ta ti/na i)/doi, he asked whom he had seen (i.e. τίνα εἶδες, whom did you see?). HDT. i. 31. So i. 116: ei)/reto ko/qen la/boi .

2. The aorist subjunctive of a dependent verb. E.g. *eu)/canto swth/ria qu/sein e)/nqa prw=ton ei)s fili/an gh=n a)fi/kointo, they vowed that they would make thank offerings for their deliverance wherever they should first enter a friendly land (i.e. ἔνθα ἂν . . . ἀφικώμεθα, θύσομεν). XEN. An. v. 1, 1 (see XEN. An. iii. 2, 9).
An aorist indicative in a dependent clause of a quotation is regularly retained (689, 3).

3. The aorist subjunctive in a question of appeal (287). E.g.
*oi( *)epida/mnioi to\n qeo\n e)ph/ronto ei) paradoi=en *korinqi/ois th\n po/lin, they asked whether they should deliver up their city to the Corinthians (i.e. they asked the question, παραδῶμεν τὴν πόλιν; shall we deliver up our city?) THUC. i. 25.
*)esko/poun o(/pws ka/llist' e)ne/gkaim' au)to/n, I looked to see how I could best endure him (i.e. I asked, πῶς ἐνέγκω αὐτόν; how can I endure him?). EUR. Hipp. 393.
*diesiw/phse skopw=n o(/ ti a)pokri/naito, he continued silent, thinking what he should answer (i.e. thinking τί ἀποκρίνωμαι;). XEN. Mem. iv. 2, 10 (See 677.)

The context must decide whether an aorist optative in an indirect question represents the aorist subjunctive (as in 3) or the aorist indicative (as in the last examples under 1). Thus the first example under 3 might mean they asked whether they had given up their city, παρέδομεν τὴν πόλιν; But in most cases the aorist subjunctive is the direct form implied, and an aorist indicative used in a direct question is generally retained; εἰ ἀναπλεύσειεν in 1 is, therefore, exceptional.

div2.head: Aorist Infinitive.
div2.p:
The aorist infinitive in indirect discourse represents an aorist indicative of the direct form. E.g.
Φησὶν τοῦτο ποιῆσαι, he says that he did this (i.e. he says τοῦτο ἐποίησα);
ἔφη τοῦτο ποιῆσαι, he said that he had done this (i.e. he said τοῦτο ἐποίησα);
φήσει τοῦτο ποιῆσαι, he will say that he did this (i.e. he will say τοῦτο ἐποίησα).
*(o *ku=ros le/getai gene/sqai *kambu/sew, Cyrus is said to have been the son of Cambyses. XEN. Cyr. i. 2, 1.
*palaio/tatoi le/gontai e)n me/rei tini\ th=s xw/ras *ku/klwpes oi)kh=sai, the Cyclops are said to have settled most anciently in a part of the country. THUC. vi. 2.
*)=hsan u(/poptoi au)toi=s mh\ proqu/mws sfi/si pe/myai a(\ e)/pemyan, they were suspected by them of not having sent to them with alacrity what they did send. THUC. vi. 75.

Although the usage of the language is very strict, by which the aorist infinitive after verbs of saying, thinking, etc. is past, as representing an aorist indicative, still several passages are found, even in the best authors, in which an aorist infinitive after such verbs as νομίζω, οἴομαι, and even φημί refers to future time. Many critics, especially Madvig,See Madvig's Bemerkungen über einige Puncte der griechischen Wortfügungslehre, pp. 34-44: Griech. Syntax, § 172a Anm. deny the existence of this anomaly, and emend the offending aorists to the future or insert ἄν. If they are allowed (and most of the passages still stand uncorrected in many editions), they must be treated as strictly exceptional; and no principle, and no consistent exception to the general principle, can be based on them. E.g.
*fa/to ga\r ti/sasqai a)lei/tas, for he said that he should punish the offenders. Od. xx. 121. (In Il. iii. 28, we have in most MSS. and editions φάτο γὰρ τίσεσθαι ἀλείτην, in precisely the same sense; but Bekker has τίσασθαι.)
So ἐφάμην τίσασθαι in Il. iii. 366.
*kai\ au)tw=| ou) me/myasqai *)apri/hn (sc. ἀπεκρίνατο): pare/sesqai ga\r kai\ au)to\s kai\ a)/llous a)/cein, and (he answered) that Apries should not have reason to blame him; for he not only would be present himself, but would bring others. HDT. ii. 162. (Notice the strange transition from the aorist (?) to the two futures.)
*fhsi\n ou)de\ th\n *dio\s *)/erin pe/dw| skh/yasan e)mpodw\n sxeqei=n AESCH. Sept. 429.
*oi)=mai ga/r nin i(keteu=sai ta/de, I think of imploring. EUR. I. A. 462. (Hermann reads ἱκετεύσειν by conjecture.)
*)eno/misan e)piqe/menoi r(a|di/ws krath=sai, they thought they should gain the victory. THUC. ii. 3.
*nomi/zw, h)\n i(ppeu\s ge/nwmai, a)/nqrwpos pthno\s gene/sqai XEN. Cyr. iv. 3, 15.
*ou)k e)/fasan e)pitre/yai tau=ta gene/sqai, they said they would not permit this to happen. LYS. xiii. 15 ; same in xiii. 47.
*tou=to de\ oi)/etai/ oi( ma/lista gene/sqai, ei) soi\ sugge/noito, and he thinks that this would be most likely to happen to him if he should join himself with you. PLAT. Prot. 316 C . (Here we should expect γενέσθαι ἄν, to correspond to εἰ συγγένοιτο.)

AR. Nub. 1141 is commonly quoted in this list, as having δικάσασθαί φασί μοι in all MSS.; but in the year 1872 I found δικάσεσθαι in Cod. Par. 2712 (Brunck's A) and by correction in 2820, so that this emendation (as it is commonly thought to be) is confirmed.
It may be thought that the aorist is less suspicious in the Homeric passages than in Attic Greek, where the uses of indirect discourse are more precisely fixed.

div2.head: Future Optative.
div2.p:
The future optative is used chiefly in indirect discourse after past tenses, to represent a future indicative of the direct form. Even here the future indicative is generally retained (670, b). E.g.
*(upeipw\n ta)/lla o(/ti au)to\s ta)kei= pra/coi, w)/|xeto, having suggested as to what remained, that he would himself attend to things there, he departed. THUC. i. 90. (Here πράξοι represents πράξω of the direct discourse, for which we might have πράξει in the indirect form. See, in the same chapter, ἀποκρινάμενοι ὅτι πέμψουσιν, having replied that they would send, where πέμψοιεν might have been used.)
*ei)/ tina feu/gonta lh/yoito, prohgo/reuen o(/ti w(s polemi/w| xrh/soito XEN. Cyr. iii. 1, 3. (Here the announcement was εἴ τινα λήψομαι, ὡς πολεμίῳ χρήσομαι.)
*)/elegen o(/ti e(/toimos ei)/h h(gei=sqai au)toi=s ei)s to\ *de/lta, e)/nqa polla\ lh/yointo XEN. An. vii. 1, 33. (He said ἕτοιμός εἰμι . . . ἔνθα λήψεσθε.) Here belongs the rare use after ἐλπίς in THUC. vi. 30, met' e)lpi/dos te a(/ma kai\ o)lofurmw=n, ta\ me\n w(s kth/sointo, tou\s d' ei)/ pote o)/yointo , i.e. (they sailed) with hope and lamentations at once, — hope that they might acquire Sicily, lamentations at the thought whether they should ever see their friends again (ὀψόμεθα; ).

The future optative occurs first in Pindar, in an indirect question, e)ke/leusen diakri=nai a(/ntina sxh/soi tis h(rw/wn, to decide which maiden each of the heroes should take (τίνα σχήσει;), Py. ix. 126 . It is used chiefly by the Attic prose writers, as the correlative of the future indicative, that tense having had no corresponding optative form in the older language, as the present, perfect, and aorist indicative and subjunctive had. It is never used with ἄν.

Apart from its use after verbs of saying and thinking, the future optative is found in object clauses with ὅπως after verbs of striving, etc. (339). Here its use is closely akin to that in indirect discourse, as it always represents thought which was originally expressed by the future indicative. E.g.
*)epemelei=to o(/pws mh/te a)/sitoi mh/te a)/potoi e)/sointo, he took care that they should be neither without food nor without drink (his thought was ὅπως μήτε . . . ἔσονται). XEN. Cyr. viii. 1, 43.
*)epemelh/qh o(/pws oi( stratiw=tai tou\s po/nous dunh/sointo u(pofe/rein Ag. ii. 8.
*mhde\n oi)/ou a)/llo mhxana=sqai, h)\ o(/pws h(mi=n o(/ti ka/llista tou\s no/mous de/cointo w(/sper bafh/n PLAT. Rep. 430A.
See Tim. 18C, mhxanwme/nous o(/pws mhdei\s gnw/soito, nomiou=si de\ pa/ntes (where γνώσοιτο represents γνώσεται, while the next word νομιοῦσι is retained in the indicative).
*)esko/pei o( *meneklh=s o(/pws mh\ e)/soito a)/pais, a)ll' e)/soito au)tw=| o(/stis zw=nta/ te ghrotrofh/soi kai\ teleuth/santa qa/yoi au)to/n, kai\ ei)s to\n e)/peita xro/non ta\ nomizo/mena au)tw=| poih/soi Menecles took thought that he might not be childless, but might have some one to support his old age while he lived and to bury him when he died, etc. ISAE. ii. 10 (see 134). Other examples are XEN. Cyr. viii. 1, 10 ; XEN. Hell. vii. 5, 3 ; XEN. Oec. vii. 5; PLAT. Ap. 36 C; ISOC. xxi. 13; ISAE. vi. 35; DEM. xxvii. 40 (ὅπως μισθώσοιτο, in the MSS.) In XEN. Hell. ii. 1, 22 we have ὡς with the future optative: προεῖπεν ὡς μηδεὶς κινήσοιτο ἐκ τῆς τάξεως μηδὲ ἀνάξοιτο.
In all such cases the future indicative is generally retained (340).

The future optative is found in four passages after verbs of fearing, three times with μή, and once with ὅπως μή:—
*kate/bale to\ *(hraklewtw=n tei=xos, ou) tou=to fobou/menos, mh/ tines poreu/sointo e)pi\ th\n e)kei/nou du/namin, not fearing this, ,lest any should march into his dominions. XEN. Hell. vi. 4, 27. So XEN. Mem. i. 2, 7.
*)alla\ kai\ tou\s qeou\s a)\n e)/deisas parakinduneu/ein, mh\ ou)k o)rqw=s au)to\ poih/sois PLAT. Euthyphr. 15 D.
*ou) mo/non peri\ th=s basa/nou kai\ th=s di/khs e)dedoi/kei, a)lla\ kai\ peri\ tou= grammatei/ou, o(/pws mh\ u(po\ tou= *menece/nou sullhfqh/soito ISOC. xvii. 22. (Here the fear was expressed originally by ὅπως μὴ συλληφθήσεται, 370).
As μή with the future indicative is rare after verbs of fearing (367), it is still rarer with the future optative after such verbs.

No case is quoted of the future optative in a pure final clause, except a peculiar one with μή in PLAT. Rep. 393 E: *)agame/mnwn h)gri/ainen, e)ntello/menos nu=n te a)pie/nai kai\ au)=qis mh\ e)lqei=n, mh\ au)tw=| to/ te skh=ptron kai\ ta\ tou= qeou= ste/mmata ou)k e)parke/soi . (Another reading, ἐπαρκέσειεν, of inferior authority, is adopted by Bekker.) If ἐπαρκέσοι is retained (as it is by most editors), it can be explained only by assuming that Plato had in his mind μὴ οὐκ ἐπαρκέσει as the direct form. Μή final with the future indicative occurs in Aristophanes, Homer, and Theognis (see 324); there is therefore no objection to μὴ ἐπαρκέσοι as representing μὴ ἐπαρκέσει. We must remember that Plato is here paraphrasing Homer (Il. i. 25-28), but by no means literally. The Homeric line is Μή νύ τοι οὐ χραίσμῃ σκῆπτρον καὶ στέμμα θεοῖο (see 263).
As ἵνα never takes the future indicative, it can never have the future optative.

A future optative rarely occurs in a relative clause of purpose after a past tense; as ai(reqe/ntes e)f' w(=|te suggra/yai no/mous, kaq' ou(/stinas politeu/sointo, having been chosen for the purpose of making a code of laws, by which they were to govern. XEN. Hell. ii. 3, 11. (Here we have an indirect expression of the thought of those who chose the Thirty, of which the direct form is found in XEN. Hell. ii. 3, 2, e)/doce tria/konta a)/ndras e(le/sqai, oi(\ tou\s patri/ous no/mous cuggra/yousi, kaq' ou(\s politeu/sousi .) See ISAE. ii. 10 (quoted in 130).

div2.head: Future Infinitive.
div2.p:
The future infinitive is regularly used only in indirect discourse (111, 112), where it always represents a future indicative of the direct form. E.g. Γράψειν φησίν, he says that he will write; γράψειν ἔφη, he said that he would write; γράψειν φήσει, he will say that he will write: all representing γράψω, I will write.
*pollou/s ge e)/sesqai e)/legon tou\s e)qelh/sontas, they said that there would be many who would be willing. XEN. Cyr. iii. 2, 26.

Verbs of hoping, expecting, promising, swearing, and a few others of like meaning, form an intermediate class between those which take the infinitive in indirect discourse (with the time of its tense preserved) and those which do not. When these refer to a future object, they regularly take the future infinitive in indirect discourse; but they also allow the aorist and even the present infinitive (not in indirect discourse), like verbs of wishing, etc. Examples are given of different verbs of this class with both constructions:—
*trwsi\n d' e)/lpeto qumo\s nh=as e)niprh/sein ktene/ein q' h(/rwas *)axaiou/s Il. xv. 701.
*)ee/lpeto ku=dos a)re/sqai, he was hoping to obtain glory. Il. xii. 407.
*)/hlpizon ga\r ma/xhn e)/sesqai for they expected that there would be a battle. THUC. iv. 71.
*)en e)lpi/di w)\n ta\ tei/xh ai(rh/sein THUC. vii. 46.
*)elpi/zei du/nato\s ei)=nai a)/rxein, he hopes to be able to rule. PLAT. Rep. 573 C . (Compare εἶναι in HDT. i. 22 and 30, quoted in 118.)
*pa/lin e)/mol' a(\ pa/ros ou)/pote h)/lpisen paqei=n EUR. H.F. 746.
*ei) ga\r krath/seian tw=| nautikw=|, to\ *(rh/gion h)/lpizon r(a|di/ws xeirw/sasqai, they hoped to subdue Rhegium. THUC. iv. 24.
*ou)d' a)\n e)lpi\s h)=n au)ta\ belti/w gene/sqai, there would not be even a hope of their becoming better. DEM. iv. 2.
Besides these constructions, ἐλπίζω (or ἐλπίς) has the infinitive with ἄν in THUC. vii. 61; ὡς with the future indicative in EUR. El. 919, with the future optative in THUC. vi. 30 (see 128), with the aorist optative and ἄν in THUC. v. 9; ὅπως with the future indicative in SOPH. El. 963, EUR. Her. 1051.
*to\n strathgo\n prosdokw= tau=ta pra/cein XEN. An. iii. 1, 14.
*mene/lewn prosdo/ka molei=n, expect M. to come. AESCH. Ag. 675.
*prosdokw=n r(a|di/ws u(ma=s e)capath=sai ISAE. xi. 22.
*(upo/ t' e)/sxeto kai\ kate/neusen dwse/menai Il. xiii. 368.
*)ek tou/tou u(pe/sxeto mhxanh\n pare/cein XEN. Cyr. vi. 1, 21.
*su\ ga\r u(pe/sxou zhth/sein PLAT. Rep. 427E.
*(uposxo/menos mh\ pro/sqen pau/sasqai pri\n au)tou\s kataga/goi oi)/kade, having promised not to stop until he had restored them to their homes. XEN. An. i. 2, 2.
*(upe/sxeto moi bouleu/sesqai
Ib. ii. 3, 20.
*(wmolo/ghsa ei)s th/meron pare/sesqai.
Symp. 174A
*(omologh/sante poih/sein to\ keleuo/menon. Id. Phaedr. 254 B So ANT. vi. 23; AND. i. 62. Compare φαμὲν τοῦτον ὡμολογηκέναι ταῦτα ποιήσειν with φάσκοντές σε ὡμολογηκέναι πολιτεύεσθαι, PLAT. Crit. 51E and 52D See Crit. 52 C; and compare cune/qou politeu/esqai, ib. 52 D
*)epei/sqhn th\n su/nodon th=| o)gdo/h| o(mologh=sai poih/sasqai, DEM. xlii. 12.
*)hggua=to mhde\n au)tou\s kako\n pei/sesqai, he pledged himself that they should suffer no harm. XEN. An. vii. 4, 13.
*prosagagw\n e)gguhta\s h)= mh\n poreu/esqai, having given securities as a pledge that he would go. Id. Cyr. vi. 2, 39.
*kai\ dh/ moi ge/ras au)to\s a)fairh/sesqai a)peilei=s Il. i. 161. So xv. 179; Od. xi. 313; HDT. vi. 37; EUR. Med. 287.
*)hpei/lhsen nh=as a(/lad' e(lke/men Il. ix. 682.
*)hpei/lhsan a)poktei=nai a(/pantas tou\s e)n th=| oi)ki/a| XEN. Hell. v. 4, 7.
*ta/xa ou)de/na ei)ko\s su\n au)tw=| boulh/sesqai ei)=nai, it is likely that soon nobody will want to be with him. XEN. Cyr. v. 3, 30.
*)ek me\n tou= kakw=s pra/ttein ta\s po/leis metabolh=s tuxei=n e)pi\ to\ be/ltion ei)ko/s e)stin, e)k de\ tou= panta/pasi gene/sqai a)na/staton kai\ tw=n koinw=n e)lpi/dwn sterhqh=nai LYCURG. 60.
*)/omosson h)= mh/n moi a)rh/cein Il. i. 76 ; so x. 321.
*)omo/sas a)pa/cein oi)/kad), e)s *troi/an m' a)/gei SOPH. Ph. 941 ; cf. Ph. 594, Ph. 623.
*)omo/santes tau/tais e)mmenei=n XEN. Hell. v. 3, 26.
*)anagka/zei to\n *kersoble/pthn o)mo/sai ei)=nai me\n th\n a)rxh\n koinh\n, pa/ntas d' u(mi=n a)podou=nai th\n xw/ran DEM. xxiii. 170.

div2.head: Future Perfect.
div2.p: The future perfect of the dependent moods is rare, except in verbs whose perfect has the meaning of a present (49), where it is an ordinary future (82).

When it occurs in other verbs, it is only in the infinitive of indirect discourse. E.g. *tau=ta ( e)/fh ) pepra/cesqai duoi=n h)\ triw=n h(merw=n, he said that we should see these things already accomplished within two or three days. DEM. xix. 74. (Here the direct discourse was πεπράξεται ταῦτα, these things will have been already accomplished.)

div2.head: III. Tenses of the Participle.
div2.p: The tenses of the participle generally express time present, past, or future relatively to the time of the verb with which they are connected.
The uses of the participle with ἄν are not included here. For these see Chapter III.

div2.head: Present Participle.
div2.p:
The present participle generally represents an action as going on at the time of its leading verb. E.g.
Τοῦτο ποιοῦσιν νομίζοντες δίκαιον εἶναι, they do this thinking it is just.
Ἐποίουν νομίζοντες, they were doing it in the thought, etc.
Ἐποίησαν νομίζοντες, they did it in the thought, etc.
Ποιήσουσιν νομίζοντες, they will do it in the thought, etc.
*tau=t' e)pra/xqh *ko/nwnos strathgou=ntos, these things were done when Conon was general. ISOC. ix. 56. (Στρατηγοῦντος is present relatively to ἐπράχθη.)
*kai/toi tau=ta pra/ttwn ti/ e)poi/ei; now in doing this what was he doing? DEM. ix. 15.
*tau=ta periidei=n gigno/mena, to see this go on. DEM. xviii. 63.

The present participle is also used as an imperfect, like the present infinitive (119). With the participle this use is not confined (as it is with the infinitive) to indirect discourse. E.g.
*oi( sumpresbeu/ontes kai\ paro/ntes katamarturh/sousin, those who were his colleagues on the embassy and who were present will testify. DEM. xix. 129. (Here the embassy is referred to as a well-known event in the past.)
Φαίνεται γὰρ ἡ νῦν Ἑλλὰς καλουμένη οὐ πάλαι βεβαίως οἰκουμένη, ἀλλὰ μεταναστάσεις τε οὖσαι τὰ πρότερα, καὶ ῥᾳδίως ἕκαστοι τὴν ἑαυτῶν ἀπολείποντες, i.e. the following things are evident, Ἑλλὰς οὐ πάλαι βεβαίως ᾠκεῖτο, ἀλλὰ μεταναστάσεις ἦσαν, καὶ ἕκαστοι τὴν ἑαυτῶν ἀπέλειπον. THUC. i. 2.
*oi)=da to
 *swkra/thn deiknu/nta toi=s cunou=sin e(auto
 kalo
 ka)gaqo
 o)/nta: oi)=da de\ ka)kei/nw swfronou=nte e)/ste *swkra/tei sunh/sthn XEN. Mem. i. 2, 18. (The direct discourse was ἐδείκνυ and ἐσωφρονείτην.)

In THUC. iv. 3, h( *pu/los e)sti\n e)n th=| *messhni/a| pote\ ou)/sh| gh=| , Pylos is in the country which was once Messenia, οὔσῃ is imperfect, and denotes time absolutely past, as is shown by ποτέ, without which it would be the country which is (now) Messenia.

An attributive present participle (824) occasionally refers to time absolutely present, even when the leading verb is not present. This is always denoted by νῦν or some other word in the context. E.g.
*th\n nu=n *boiwti/an kaloume/nhn w)/|khsan, they settled in the country now called Boeotia. THUC. i. 12.
*(o toi/nun *fi/lippos e)c a)rxh=s, ou)/pw *diopei/qous strathgou=ntos, ou)de\ tw=n o)/ntwn e)n *xerronh/sw| nu=n a)pestalme/nwn, *se/rreion kai\ *dori/skon e)la/mbane, Philip then in the beginning, when Diopeithes was not yet general, and when the soliders who ARE NOW in the Chersonese had not yet been sent out, seized upon Serrium and Doriscus. DEM. ix. 15. (Here στρατηγοῦντος is present to the time of ἐλάμβανε, while ὄντων is present to the time of speaking.)
For a corresponding use of the aorist participle, see 152.

div2.head: Perfect Participle.
div2.p:
The perfect participle in all its uses represents an action as already finished at the time of its leading verb. E.g.
Ἐπαινοῦσι τοὺς εἰρηκότας, they praise those who have spoken.
Ἐπῄνεσαν τοὺς εἰρηκότας, they praised those who had spoken.
Ἐπαινέσουσι τοὺς εἰρηκότας, they will praise those who will (then) have spoken.
*)epe/deica ou)de\n a)lhqe\s a)phggelko/ta ( *ai)sxi/nhn ), I showed that Aeschines had announced nothing that was true (i.e. I showed, οὐδὲν ἀληθὲς ἀπήγγελκεν). DEM. xix. 177.
*tou\s desmw/tas meteme/lonto a)podedwko/tes, they repented of having restored the captives. THUC. v. 35.
*th=s *ai)oli/dos xalepw=s e)/feren a)pesterhme/nos, he took it hard that he had been deprived of Aeolis. XEN. Hell. iii. 2, 13.

div2.head: Aorist Participle.
div2.p:
The aorist participle generally represents an action as past with reference to the time of its leading verb. E.g.
Ταῦτα ποιήσαντες ἀπελθεῖν βούλονται, having done this, they (now) wish to go away.
Ταῦτα εἰπόντες ἀπῆλθον, having said this, they went away.
*ou) polloi\ fai/nontai cunelqo/ntes, not many appear to have joined in the expedition. THUC. i. 10.
*boiwtoi\ e)c *)/arnhs a)nasta/ntes th\n *boiwti/an w)/|khsan, Boeotians who had been driven from Arne settled Boeotia. THUC. i. 12.
*)/efamen ou)/te e)pisth/mhn ou)/te a)/gnoian e)p' au)tw=| e)/sesqai, a)lla\ to\ metacu\ au)= fane\n a)gnoi/as kai\ e)pisth/mhs, i.e. we said that it would be the province of neither knowledge nor ignorance, but of that which should have appeared (φανέν) in due course between these. PLAT. Rep. 478D . (Here φανέν is past to ἔσεσθαι, though absolutely future; see 22.)
*)afi/keto deu=ro to\ ploi=on, gno/ntwn tw=n *kefallh/nwn, a)ntipra/ttontos tou/tou, e)ntau=qa kataplei=n au)to/, the vessel arrived here, the Cephallenians having determined that it should return to this port, although this man opposed it. DEM. xxxii. 14. (Here γνόντων denotes time past relatively to ἀφίκετο, and ἀντιπράττοντος time present relatively to γνόντων, which is its leading verb.)

When the aorist participle is used with any form of λανθάνω, to escape the notice of, τυγχάνω, to happen, and φθάνω, to anticipate, except the present and imperfect, it does not denote time past with reference to the verb, but coincides with it in time. Thus ἔλαθον ἀπελθόντες means they went away secretly (= ἀπῆλθον λάθρα); οὐκ ἔφθησαν ἀπελθόντες, no sooner were they gone (= οὐ πρότερον ἀπῆλθον); ἔτυχον εἰσελθόντες, they came in by chance, or they happened to come in (= εἰσῆλθον τύχῃ). E.g.
*tou\s d' e)/laq' ei)selqw\n *pri/amos, and Priam entered unnoticed by them. Il. xxiv. 477 ; so xvii. 2 and 89.
*)/elaqen ( au)th\n ) a(fqe/nta pa/nta kai\ kataflexqe/nta, everything took fire and was consumed before she knew it. THUC. iv. 133.
*lanqa/nei (historic present) sth/lhn pai/sas SOPH. El. 744.
*)/efqh o)reca/menos, he aimed a blow first. Il. xvi. 322.
*au)toi\ fqh/sontai au)to\ dra/santes, they will do it first themselves. PLAT. Rep. 375 C .
*ou) ga\r e)/fqh moi sumba=sa h( a)tuxi/a, kai\ eu)qu\s e)pexei/rhsan, k.t.l. for no sooner did this misfortune come upon me, than they undertook, etc. DEM. lvii. 65 .
*stratia\ ou) pollh\ e)/tuxe me/xri *)isqmou= parelqou=sa, an army of no great size had by chance marched as far as the Isthmus. THUC. vi. 61.
*)/etuxe de\ kata\ tou=to tou= kairou= e)lqw/n, and he happened to come just at that moment. Id. vii. 2.
*)oli/ga pro\s ta\ me/llonta tuxei=n pra/cantes (sc. ἡγοῦνται), they think that it was their fortune to accomplish only a little in comparison with their expectations. Id. i. 70. So tou=t' e)/tuxon labw/n, I happened to take this, AR. Eccl. 375.
*(oppo/tero/s ke fqh=|sin o)reca/menos xro/a kalo/n whichever shall first hit, etc. Il. xxiii. 805.
*bouloi/mhn a)\n laqei=n au)to\n a)pelqw/n, I should like to get away without his knowing it. XEN. An. i. 3, 17.
*tou\s a)nqrw/pous lh/somen e)pipeso/ntes
Ib. vii. 3. 43
*eu)labei=sqai parekeleu/esqe a)llh/lois, o(/pws mh\ pe/ra tou= de/ontos sofw/teroi geno/menoi lh/sete diafqare/ntes, you exhorted one another to take care not to become wise overmuch and so get corrupted unawares. PLAT. Gorg. 487D . (Here γενόμενοι is an ordinary aorist, past with reference to the future phrase λήσετε διαφθαρέντες.)
The last four examples show that this use of the aorist participle is allowed even when both participle and verb refer to the future.
The aorist participle has the same use with συμπίπτω, to happen, in Herodotus (890). E.g. *kai\ to/de e(/teron sune/pese geno/menon, and this other event occurred (as it chanced). HDT. ix. 101.
So συγκυρέω in HDT. viii. 87 (see 889).

An aorist participle with the present or imperfect of any of the above verbs (144) cannot coincide with the verb in time, and retains its own reference to past time. This combination seldom occurs.For the examples of τυγχάνω here given I am indebted to an unpublished paper on this construction by Dr. James R. Wheeler, in which notice of this peculiarity is taken for the first time (so far as I am aware). E.g.
*(/oper labou=sa tugxa/nei mh/thr xeroi=n, which, as it happens, the mother has taken in her hands (happens to have taken). EUR. Bacch. 1140.
*)/arista tugxa/nousi pra/cantes, it happens that they fared the best. ISOC. iv. 103.
*dikai/ws a)\n th\n au)th\n eu)ergesi/an a)pola/boimen, h(/nper au)toi\ tugxa/nomen ei)s u(ma=s u(pa/rcantes, we should justly receive back the same kindness which it is our own fortune to have first shown to you (we happen to have begun. Id. xiv. 57.
*pro\s ti/ tou=t' ei)pw\n kurei=s; wherefore did you chance to speak thus (does it chance that you spoke)? SOPH. El. 1176.
*pou= kurei= e)kto/pios suqei/s; Id. OC 119.
*(/ora kaq' u(/pnon mh\ kataulisqei\s kurh=|, see lest it may chance that he has retired to sleep within. Id. Ph. 30.
Compare suneku/rhse parapesou=sa, happened to collide. HDT. viii. 87
(889). *mi=cis mi/a lu/phs te kai\ h(donh=s cumpi/ptei genome/nh, i.e. happens to have occurred (Badham proposes γιγνομένη). Phil. 47d
*ou)d' a)/ra *ki/rkhn e)c *)ai/dew e)lqo/ntes e)lh/qomen, nor was it unknown to Circe that we had returned from Hades. Od. xii. 16.
*(/osoi e)tu/gxanon ou(/tws a)qro/oi cunecelqo/ntes, all who happened to have thus come out together. THUC. iii. 111.
*ei)/ ti/ pou ai)gw=n perileifqe\n e)tu/gxane ge/nos, if any race of goats happened to have been left. Leg. 677E.
*)aristago/rh| de\ sune/pipte tou= au)tou= xro/nou pa/nta sunelqo/nta, and it was the fortune of A. that all these came to him at the same time. HDT. v. 36. (Here it is difficult to distinguish the doubly past time; but the analogy of the other examples, and the difficulty of conceiving an imperfect and aorist as coincident in time, seem decisive.)
*)orqw=s sfi h( fh/mh sune/baine e)lqou=sa, rightly, as it happened, had the report come to them. Id. ix. 101.
Just below: th=s au)th=s h(me/rhs sune/baine gi/nesqai, i.e. they (the battles of Plataea and Mycale) happened to fall on the same day. (9.101)

In LYS. xii. 27 we have the aorist and perfect participles together with ἐτύγχανε, each expressing its own time: ὅστις ἀντειπών γε ἐτύγχανε καὶ γνώμην ἀποδεδειγμένος, who charced to have spoken in opposition and to have shown his opinion.

It appears from these examples that the aorist participle can coincide in its time only with forms which have a similar aoristic or complexive meaning, while in other cases the verb and participle are distinct in time.

1. The perfect participle can always be used with the verbs of 144 to denote an action which is completed at the time of the leading verb. This is the most common way of expressing past time in the participle here. E.g.
*)etu/gxanon a)/rti pareilhfo/tes th\n a)rxh/n, they happened to have just received their authority. THUC. vi. 96.
*)ea/n tis h)dikhkw/s ti tugxa/nh| th\n po/lin, if it ever happens that one has wronged the city. DEM. xviii. 123.
So THUC. i. 103 (see 887).
2. The present participle with these verbs is regular, representing an action as going on at the time of the verb. See PLAT. Crit. 49B and the four following examples (with others), in 887.

In many constructions in which the aorist participle follows a verb in the sense of the ordinary object infinitive (not in indirect discourse), it does not refer to past time, but differs from the present participle only as the aorist infinitive in such a construction would differ from the present (96). This applies especially to the participle with περιορῶ and ἐφορῶ (περιεῖδον, ἐπεῖδον), in the sense of allow, not interfere with, and ὁρῶ (εἶδον) permit and see (cf. 884 and 885). E.g.
*prosdexo/menos tou\s *)aqhnai/ous katoknh/sein periidei=n au)th
 [th
 gh=n] tmhqei=san, a)nei=xen, expecting that they would be unwilling to see their land ravaged, etc. THUC. ii. 18. But in ii. 20 we find the aorist infinitive, ἤλπιζεν τὴν γῆν οὐκ ἂν περιιδεῖν τμηθῆναι, would not let their land be ravaged, referring to precisely the same event from another point of view (see 903, 6).
*mh\ perii/dhte h(me/as diafqare/ntas, do not look on and see us destroyed. HDT. iv. 118.
*ou) mh/ s' e)gw\ perio/yomai a)pelqo/nta, I will by no means let you go. AR. Ran. 509.
*)/etlhsan e)pidei=n e)rh/mhn me
 th
 po/lin genome/nhn th
 de\ xw/ran porqoume/nhn, a(/panta de\ to
 po/lemon peri\ th
 patri/da th
 au(tw=n gigno/menon. ISOC. iv. 96. (Here the aorist participle denotes the laying waste of the city (as a single act), while the presents denote the continuous ravaging of the country and the gradual coming on of a state of war. This is precisely the difference between the present and aorist infinitive in similar constructions.)
*)epei=don th
 e(autw=n patri/da a)na/staton genome/nhn. ANT. v. 79.

*ei) kei=no/n ge i)/doimi katelqo/nt' *)/aidos ei)/sw, if I should see him go down and enter Hades. Il. vi. 284.
*mh/ m' i)dei=n qano/nq' u(p' a)stw=n, not to see me killed by the citizens. EUR. Or. 746.
*dia\ to\ swfronei=n tw=| pw/pot' ei)=des h)/dh a)gaqo/n ti geno/menon; AR. Nub. 1061.
Ὅταν αὐτὸν ἴδῃ ἐξαίφνης πταίσαντα πρὸς τῇ πόλει καὶ ἐκχέαντα τά τε αὑτοῦ καὶ ἑαυτὸν, . . . ἢ ἀποθανόντα ἢ ἐκπεσόντα ἢ ἀτιμωθέντα καὶ τὴν οὐσίαν ἅπασαν ἀποβαλόντα. PLAT. Rep. 553A. So Rep. 498D, Prot. 324B; AESCH. Supp. 423; SOPH. Ant. 476.

So after ἀκούω; as αἴ κ’ ἐθέλῃς’ εἰπόντος ἀκουέμεν, in case he will hear me speak, Il. vi. 281.
*tosau=ta fwnh/santos ei)shkou/samen, so much we heard him say. SOPH. O.C. 1645. So also πραθέντα τλῆναι, endured to be sold, AESCH. Ag. 1041; σπείρας ἔτλα, Sept. 754: for τλάω with the regular infinitive, see ISOC. iv. 96, quoted above. So μένειν νοστήσαντα ἄνακτα, to await the king's return, Il. xiii. 38.

The aorist participle loses its reference to past time also in the peculiar construction in which the participle with its noun has the force of the infinitive with its subject; as μετὰ Συρακούσας οἰκισθείσας, after the founding of Syracuse (= μετὰ τὸ Συρακούσας οἰκισθῆναι), THUC. vi. 3.See examples in 829 (b).

An aorist participle denoting that in which the action of a verb of past time consists (845) may express time coincident with that of the verb, when the actions of the verb and the participle are practically one.See the discussion of this, with especial reference to the New Testament, where examples of this kind are frequent, by Professor W. G. Ballantine, in the Bibliotheca Sacra for October 1884, p. 787. E.g. *neu=s' e)pi\ oi(= kale/sas, he called him to him by a nod. Od. xvii. 330.
Βῆ ἀίξασα. Il. ii. 167. Εὖ γ’ ἐποίησας ἀναμνήσας με, you did well in reminding me. PLAT. Phaed. 60 C. Μή τι ἐξαμάρτητε ἐμοῦ καταψηφισάμενοι, lest you make any mistake in condemning me. Id. Ap. 30D . Παῖδα κατακανὼν ξυήλῃ πατάξας, having killed a child by the stroke of a dagger. XEN. An. iv. 8, 25. Ἤδη πώποτε οὖν ἢ δακοῦσα κακόν τί σοι ἔδωκεν ἢ λακτίσασα; did your mother ever do you any harm by biting or kicking you? Id. Mem. ii. 2, Id. Mem. 7. Πέμπει ὡς τὸν Ἀστύοχον κρύφα ἐπιστείλας ὅτι Ἀλκιβιάδης αὐτῶν τὰ πράγματα φθείρει, i.e. he sends a private message, etc. THUC. viii. 50.After a perfect: ὅς’ ἡμᾶς ἀγαθὰ δέδρακας εἰρήνην ποιήσας, what blessings you have done us in making a peace! Pac. 1199.
The following examples among many in the New Testament illustrate the usage:—

Ἀποκριθεὶς εἶπεν ἐν παραβολαῖς αὐτοῖς, λέγων, he answered and spake to them in parables, and said. MATTH. xxii. 1. (Λέγων is the ordinary present, less closely connected with εἶπον than ἀποκριθείς.) Προσευξάμενοι εἶπαν, they prayed and said. Act. Apost. i. 24. Καλῶς ἐποίησας παραγενόμενος, thou hast well done that thou art come. Ib. x. 33.

In such passages as w(molo/ghsan toi=s *)aqhnai/ois tei/xh te perielo/ntes kai\ nau=s parado/ntes fo/ron te taca/menoi, THUC. i. 108 , the aorist participle is past with reference to the time of the beginning of the peace to which ὡμολόγησαν refers, and the meaning is, they obtained terms of peace, on condition that they should first (before the peace began) tear down their walls, etc. Such passages are THUC. i. 101, THUC. 108, THUC. 115, THUC. 117.See Krüger's note on i. 108, and Madvig's Bemerkungen, p. 46. Madvig quotes, to confirm this view, LYS. xii. 68: ὑπέσχετο εἰρήνην ποιήσειν μήτε ὅμηρα δοὺς μήτε τὰ τείχη καθελὼν μήτε τὰς ναῦς παραδούς, i.e. he promised to make a peace without giving pledges, etc.

An attributive aorist participle occasionally refers to time absolutely past, without regard to the time of its verb. E.g. Ἡγεμόνα παρεχόμενοι Μεγάπανον τὸν Βαβυλῶνος ὕστερον τούτων ἐπιτροπεύσαντα, i.e. they had as their leader Megapanus, who after this was made governor of Babylon. HDT. vii. 62. (Here the aorist participle is past at the time of writing only; it is even future compared with the time of παρεχόμενοι.) So in vii. 106: κατέλιπε δὲ ἄνδρα τοιόνδε Μασκάμην γενόμενον, and he left M. (in authority), who (afterwards) proved himself such a man (the evidence of his later merits follows in a relative sentence).
For the corresponding use of the present participle see 141.

For the use of the aorist infinitive and participle with ἄν, see 207 and 215. For the aorist participle with ἔχω and εἶχον as a circumlocution for the perfect and pluperfect, as θαυμάσας ἔχω and εἶχον, see 47 and 48. For the rare use of the aorist participle with ἔσομαι for the future perfect, see 81. For the aorist participle in protasis, see 472 and 841.

div2.head: Future Participle.
div2.p: The future participle represents an action as future with reference to the time of its leading verb. E.g. Τοῦτο ποιήσων ἔρχεται, he is coming to do this; τοῦτο ποιήσων ἦλθεν, he came to do this. Πεμφθήσεται ταῦτα ἐρῶν, he will be sent to say this. Οἶδα αὐτὸν τοῦτο ποιήσοντα, I know that he will do this; οἶδα τοῦτο ποιήσων, I know that I shall do this; ᾔδειν αὐτὸν τοῦτο ποιήσοντα, I knew that he would do this.
For the various uses of the future participle, and examples, see Chapter VI.

div2.head: Gnomic and Iterative tenses: Gnomic Aorist and Perfect.
div2.p: The aorist and sometimes the perfect indicative are used in animated language to express general truths. These are called the gnomic aorist and the gnomic perfect, and are usually to be translated by our present.

These tenses give a more vivid statement of general truths, by employing a distinct case or several distinct cases in the past to represent (as it were) all possible cases, and implying that what has occurred is likely to occur again under similar circumstances. E.g. *ka/tqan' o(mw=s o(/ t' a)ergo\s a)nh o(/ te polla\ e)orgw/s, the idle man and he who has laboured much alike must die. Il. ix. 320.
*(/oste kai\ a)/lkimon a)/ndra fobei= kai\ a)fei/leto ni/khn, who terrifies even a valiant man and snatches his victory away. Il. xvii. 177 (see 157, below). *bi/a kai\ mega/lauxon e)/sfalen e)n xro/nw| PIND. Py. viii. 15. . *sofoi\ de\ me/llonta tritai=on a)/nemon e)/maqon, ou)d' u(po\ ke/rdei bla/ben Nem. vii. 17. . *kai\ dh\ fi/lon tis e)/ktan' a)gnoi/as u(/po, and now one may kill a friend through ignorance. AESCH. Supp. 499.
*)alla\ ta\ toiau=ta ei)s me
 a(/pac kai\ braxu
 xro/non a)nte/xei, kai\ sfo/dra ge h)/nqhsen e)pi\ tai=s e)lpi/sin, a)
 tu/xh|, tw=| xro/nw| de\ fwra=tai kai\ peri\ au(ta\ katarrei= DEM. ii. 10 (see 157 and 171). *)\hn a)/ra sfalw=sin, a)ntelpi/santes a)/lla e)plh/rwsan th

*)\hn de/ tis tou/twn ti parabai/nh|, zhmi/an au)toi=s e)pe/qesan, they impose a penalty upon every one who transgresses. XEN. Cyr. i. 2, 2.
*deinw=n t' a)/hma pneuma/twn e)koi/mise ste/nonta po/nton SOPH. Aj. 674.

*(/otan o( *)/erws e)gkrate/steros ge/nhtai, diafqei/rei te polla\ kai\ h)di/khsen Symp. 188A.
*(/otan tis w(/sper ou(=tos i)sxu/sh|, h( prw/th pro/fasis kai\ mikro
